com.github.mmichaelis.hamcrest.nextdeed.concurrent

Interface ProbeBuilder<T,R>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of system you are probing
    R - the type of state variable you are polling
    All Superinterfaces:
    ProbeAssert<T,R>, ProbeAssume<T,R>, ProbeRequire<T,R>, WaitBuilder

    public interface ProbeBuilder<T,R>
extends WaitBuilder, ProbeAssert<T,R>, ProbeAssume<T,R>, ProbeRequire<T,R>
    Builder for Probes. In contrast WaitBuilder which only contains any wait-specific methods the ProbeBuilder contains methods for specifying the check and fail strategies to apply. In addition you can use onTimeout(Consumer) to get informed in timeouts and possibly create more debugging information like database dumps, screenshots, ...

    • Method Detail

      • withinMs

        @NotNull
ProbeBuilder<T,R> withinMs(long timeoutMs)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder

        How much time it might take to fulfill predicate. Otherwise time out.

        Mind that the timeout is not hard regarding the system response time. If your timeout is 100 ms but the system takes 1000 ms to answer and assuming the state is reached, the call is still successful. In other words: This is not to guarantee certain time measures – but to give some grace to the system to reach the wanted state.

        Specified by:
        withinMs in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        timeoutMs - timeout in milliseconds; must be greater than or equal to 0
        Returns:
        self-reference

        How much time it might take to fulfill predicate. Otherwise time out.

        Mind that the timeout is not hard regarding the system response time. If your timeout is 100 ms but the system takes 1000 ms to answer and assuming the state is reached, the call is still successful. In other words: This is not to guarantee certain time measures – but to give some grace to the system to reach the wanted state.

        Specified by:

      • withFinalGracePeriodMs

        @NotNull
ProbeBuilder<T,R> withFinalGracePeriodMs(long gracePeriodMs)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder

        Configures the grace period to grant after the timeout is reached.

        Example:

        Your system responds within 100 ms and you start with an initial delay at 0 ms. Having a timeout of 140 ms the remaining sleep time after first failure is 40 ms. But giving a grace of 50 ms will cause the last sleep to take 90 ms thus giving the system more chances to reach the wanted state.

        Specified by:
        withFinalGracePeriodMs in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        gracePeriodMs - grace period in milliseconds; must be greater than or equal to 0
        Returns:
        self-reference

But giving a grace of 50 ms will cause the last sleep to take 90 ms thus giving the system more chances to reach the wanted state.

      • withInitialDelayMs

        @NotNull
ProbeBuilder<T,R> withInitialDelayMs(long initialDelayMs)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder

        The initial delay and also base delay for polling. The default initial delay is 0 milliseconds.

        Note:
        As the polling will never increase but only decrease the initial delay is also the minimum polling interval. It might be used, if you know that your system for example takes at least two seconds to recover from a request.
        Specified by:
        withInitialDelayMs in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        initialDelayMs - initial delay in milliseconds; must be greater than or equal to 0
        Returns:
        self-reference

      • deceleratePollingBy

        @NotNull
ProbeBuilder<T,R> deceleratePollingBy(double decelerationFactor)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder
        Factor by which the polling interval is decelerated. Greater values will decelerate more, a value of 1 won't decelerate at all but keep the polling interval.
        Specified by:
        deceleratePollingBy in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        decelerationFactor - factor to decelerate; must be greater than or equal to 1
        Returns:
        self-reference

      • onTimeout

        @NotNull
ProbeBuilder<T,R> onTimeout(@NotNull
                                      Consumer<WaitTimeoutEvent<T,R>> eventConsumer)

        On timeout specify a consumer which will be called upon timeout. The consumer is just called for information and must not mangle with the wait-lifecycle. Thus it can neither prevent the failure at the end nor should it throw exceptions on its own.

        The timeout event should provide enough information for example to dump the current system state, take screenshots, etc.

        Multiple event consumers can be registered which will be informed without any granted order.

        Parameters:
        eventConsumer - consumer for the timeout event
        Returns:
        self-reference
